p.s: Taking a closer look, the sonnet reveals many stylistic devices.
What is very striking is the anaphora that occurs in line five, nine as well as thirdteenthirteen O, how, O fearful, O, none.
Not only does the anaphora structure of the poem and guide the reader throughout the poem, but it also sounds like a helpless scream.
This allows the reader to feel the emotions this speaker has and it gives it dimension.
In line one the reader finds an enumeration nor stone, nor earth, nor boundless sea.

In context with the contents of the summit, the enumeration tries to describe how powerfullpowerful the time and its mortality towards the human kind is, by comparing it to natural phenomena that seem indestructible.
It affects the reader to have respect and maybe even fear.
Typically for a Shakespearean poem he uses many contrasts like rage and beauty (l. 3) to make his poems more interesting for the audianceaudience.
In line three and four he personificatespersonifies beauty by saying that beauty is no stronger than a flower.
By that, Shakespeare tries to explain the fragility of love and compares it to a flower.
Line five is a great example for Shakespeare's use of imagery summer's honey breath.
Imagery creates a vivid image in the readersreader's mind and leads them to feel, smell or taste what is written.

The rhetorical question shall times best jewel from time's chest lie hid? (l. 10) has the effect on the audianceaudience to not only read the sonnet but also think about what is mentioned, questioning themselfthemselves and trying to find a solution.
The solution is found in the couplet.
The speaker knows, that nothing can stop timestime's curse but the love can be put down in writing black ink (l. 14).
As long as it is written down, love and its beauty will not die but still shine bright (l. 14).
The intention of dishonored is to respect time itself and feared, but not to hide from timestime's effect that it has in every part of our lifeslives.
Shakespeare always used to write about meaningful and important themes which people could relate to.
That's what him and his sonnets are so unique.
His sonnets had a structural construct, for example his first sonnets from 1 - 126 were adressedaddressed to a young man and the others are adressedaddressed to the dark lady.
What is important to mention, also in context with the sonnet, is that his sonnets grew with Shakespeare, and love grows as well.
It has a beginning and also an end.
That means that love eventually dies.
His first sonnets were about the beauty and bright side of love.
As he wrote more sonnets, the themes and meanings got darker as well as more realistic.
That is a great way of expressing the experiences in life as an artist.
